timeline.message:
Fix MemoryRevokingScheduler from re-visiting tasks for the same query

Previously, MemoryRevokingScheduler (and its task-threshold flavored
counterpart) would find running tasks but then operate on them by
traversing their QueryContext. This led to two significant problems:
- MemoryRevokingScheduler would over-count the amount of memory that
  was already being revoked since it would traverse each task for a
  given query from all other tasks in that query.
- Both flavors of memory revoking scheduler would repeatedly perform
  the same traversals and attempt to revoke memory from the same tasks
  and operators based on the number of tasks a given query had

Add SqlTask#getTaskState() and SqlTask#getTaskCreateTime()

Avoids using comparatively more expensive methods like getTaskStats()
or getTaskStatus() when only these specific fields are required and
no particular synchronization order is being enforced.

Refactor MemoryRevokingScheduler to avoid redundant work

Avoids repeatedly traversing the tasks collection to filter running
tasks for the given memory pool and sorting them between summing the
in progress revoking and initiating subsequent revoking actions on
operators

replies.bodyText: If the refactors to the test class are applied but the fixes in MemoryRevokingScheduler are not (ie: tasks created in tests are assigned to the same real QueryContext instance) then almost all tests will fail because of the over-counting tasks within the same query bug.
replies.author: pettyjamesm
